text:
INTERVIEWER: As you
indicated, you went public.

You were one of the first
companies in The Kingdom
to go public.
What led you to that?
What made you go public?

MUHAMMAD ALAGIL: I
have to sit back.
In the 1990s first because--

I was more involved
in the family office

in the '90s in the
investment side

where we have different asset
classes and different sizes
and location.

And I needed to
mitigate some risks.

By late '90s, we start
to have young kids,

and the young kids are
probably 12, 13, 15, 14.
So I start to see some risks.
And maybe 15, 16.

They start in different
homes of the partners
thinking they are just the best.

And so we wanted to
get rid of this risk.

My thought, I wanted
to get rid of it.

So I looked at it and I
talked to some other friends.

And actually, I first
picked up in New York.

I mean, somebody
I've seen in Saudi,

but he's actually
in New York for work

for a Middle Eastern
institution--
for Saudi institution.

I should look-- one way is
to do a private placement.

This way we have
an exterior board.

We have different committees
like audit, some governance.
And then I wanted to go public.

But he said, look,
we may have to go

through a private
placement first

because the regulations
were not very good in Saudi
at that time.

Has not been-- capital market
was not much at that time.

But now, the regulations
are extremely easy.

And then we went
public in 2003--
end of 2003.

We already have announced our
results for so many years now.

We have boards, we
have committees.
And then, there is--

INTERVIEWER: All these
things were novelties?
MUHAMMAD ALAGIL: Yeah.
At that time it was novelty.

And I wanted to mitigate
risk for second generation.
We didn't want--

INTERVIEWER: Could you
say a bit more about that?
You said that you did this--

one of the reason
you did this is

to mitigate risk and risk
coming from second generation.
MUHAMMAD ALAGIL: Yes.

INTERVIEWER: That's a
rationale for going public?

MUHAMMAD ALAGIL: I tell
you, second generation

and our wives, as
well, because they--
INTERVIEWER: Wait.
And your wives as well?
MUHAMMAD ALAGIL: Wives, yeah.
Our wives.

INTERVIEWER: Please,
please expound on that.

MUHAMMAD ALAGIL: Each one of us,
probably his wife and the kids,

they think their father
is the most important guy
in the company.

And if one of us pass
away, then my brothers

will not be able to
operate very easily.

And so we wanted to get
public to mitigate risk.

We also want to take
some money off the table.
We worked for 20-plus years.
We made good business.

And we thought maybe take
some money off the table.

And the third one,
which is not--

I don't underestimate it, but
this was my hidden agenda.
I don't think I want to--

at that time, it's
an agenda which
I shared with my brothers.

It's that I want the company
to continue because my brothers

now, they've started
to feel comfortable.
We all feel rich.
Oh, you know what?

OK, the profit was $60
million, now it's $650 million.
Well, it's OK.
Not bad.

So I actually wanted
to keep going.
